summary: 132 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A (H7N9) virus have been reported, 37 of whom have died. the novel virus infection is associated with severe clinical symptoms characterized by rapidly progressive pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome and multiorgan failure. sporadic human infections with H7N9 virus to date raise more important questions that whether this virus will persistently evolve for better adaption to humans. real-time RT-PCR has become the most popular molecular diagnostic approach in clinical laboratories owing to its simplicity, high sensitivity and specificity. real-time RT-PCR assays are usually carried out with the use of hydrolysis probe (Taqman) or SYBR green fluorescence dye. a total of 7 clinical samples (5 throat-swabs, 1 sputum and 1 tracheal aspirate) from H7N9-infected patients were collected and stored at 70°C until further analysis. a H7N9 virus isolate (A/Nanjing/1/2013) was used as the reference virus. a base close to the 3′ end of each primer would be substituted by a mixed base to ensure full complementation of several bases close to the 3′ end of each primer with the templates as possible. the number of mixed base sites within each primer was not allowed more than three positions as a general rule. real time quantitative RT-PCR assays were performed using superscript III Platinum SYBR Green One-Step qRT-PCR kit. the amplified HA and NA gene segments were then in-vitro transcribed with T7 RNA polymerase (TaKaRa, Dalian, China) the synthesized RNA transcripts were purified, quantified and mixed with equal-molar amounts. a total of 7 clinical samples (5 throat-swabs, 1 sputum and 1 tracheal aspirate) from H7N9-infected patients were collected and stored at 70°C until further analysis.
